thread.title: Brazil’s economy slips into recession

title: Brazil’s economy slips into recession
text:
Brazil’s economy slips into recession Geoff Dyer in São Paulo ©Bloomberg 
Brazil’s economy officially slipped into recession in the second quarter as high inflation, plummeting consumer confidence and a roiling corruption scandal led gross domestic product to contract 1.9 per cent from the previous quarter. 
The figure was even worse than economists had expected and was compounded by a big downward revision of first quarter data from a 0.2 per cent reduction in GDP to a 0.7 per cent decline. 
Compared with the second quarter of last year, the economy has shrunk 2.6 per cent, the Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics said on Friday. After two consecutive quarters of negative growth, officials said the economy was formally in recession. 
Continue reading 
Brazil’s economy has been beset by a series of interlinking problems that show few signs of abating. 
Corruption scandals at state-owned companies, most notably oil company Petrobras, have hit investment. Rising inflation has prompted high interest rates that are affecting consumer demand. And the government’s low popularity has limited its ability to bring the budget deficit under control, which officials believe is necessary to begin a new cycle of growth. 
The uncertainty about the fate of the economy in China — a vital customer for Brazilian commodity exports — has only added to the poor outlook for Brazil in the coming months. More Rousseff battles sense of crisis in Brazil 
“This is a shocking report,” said Neil Shearing, emerging markets economist at Capital Economics. “The driver was a complete collapse in domestic demand.” 
With unemployment also rising sharply in recent months, household spending dropped 2.1 per cent from the previous quarter, while fixed investment fell 8.1 per cent — an indication of the fallout from the scandal at Petrobras, the country’s biggest industrial company, which has also involved many of Brazil’s biggest construction companies. 
The second-quarter growth figure was the second worst since 1998, capped only by the immediate aftermath of the 2008 financial crisis. 
The GDP figures ended a week of bleak economic news from Brazil . A separate government survey revealed on Wednesday that unemployment reached 8.3 per cent in the second quarter, up from 6.8 per cent a year before, while in July alone the fiscal accounts showed a deficit of R$7.2bn (US$2bn). 
When interest payments are excluded, Brazil has so far this year recorded a budget deficit of 0.27 per cent of GDP — the first time the figure has been in deficit since the government began publishing the statistic in 1997. 
Amid such a wave of pessimistic news, the government’s efforts to rein in public spending are facing strong resistance. The latest proposal, a leaked plan to reinstate a tax on financial transactions, was sharply criticised this week by leading politicians. Renan Calheiros, the president of the Senate, called it a “shot in the foot”. 
Paulo Skaf, head of the influential São Paulo industrial federation, said on Thursday that finance minister Joaquim Levy should resign because of his efforts at new austerity measures. “A minister who only talks about raising taxes . . . Brazil does not need such a minister,” he told reporters.
